I am using the open-source data mining software Weka for running a data mining algorithm like Linear Regression. When I execute this, Weka returns a model and some metrics for evaluating the model on test data. The output looks like this:

Correlation coefficient                  0.2978
Mean absolute error                     15.5995
Root mean squared error                 29.9002
Relative absolute error                 47.7508 %
Root relative squared error             72.2651 %

I am having difficulty understanding the formula used for calculating "Relative absolute error" and "Root relative squared error". Could you provide me with these formulas? I would like to use these metrics to evaluate my own algorithms in Matlab.

Certainly! The "Relative Absolute Error" (RAE) and "Root Relative Squared Error" (RRSE) are commonly used metrics to evaluate the performance of regression models. They provide a normalized measure of error which allows for easier comparison across different models or datasets. Here's how they are calculated:

### Relative Absolute Error (RAE)

The Relative Absolute Error is calculated as the ratio of the absolute error of the model to the absolute error of a simple predictor (like the mean of the actual values). The formula is:

\[ 
\text{RAE} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} |y_i - \hat{y}_i|}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} |y_i - \bar{y}|} 
\]

- \( y_i \) is the actual value.
- \( \hat{y}_i \) is the predicted value by the model.
- \( \bar{y} \) is the mean of the actual values.
- \( n \) is the number of data points.

The RAE is usually expressed as a percentage, so you would multiply the result by 100 to obtain the percentage form.

### Root Relative Squared Error (RRSE)

The Root Relative Squared Error compares the total squared error of the model's predictions to the total squared error of a simple predictor (again, typically the mean of the actual values). The formula is:

\[
\text{RRSE} = \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (y_i - \bar{y})^2}}
\]

- The terms are defined as in the RAE.

Again, RRSE is often expressed as a percentage, so it is common to multiply by 100.

### Interpretation

- A lower RAE or RRSE indicates a better performing model.
- RAE and RRSE values less than 100% suggest that the model is predicting better than the baseline predictor (mean of the actual values).

These formulas should help you compute RAE and RRSE in MATLAB for your custom algorithms. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask!
